Description: THE MID KLAMATH WATERSHED COUNCIL'S YOUTH STEWARDSHIP PROJECT IS PROPOSED TO TAKE PLACE IN THE MIDDLE KLAMATH REGION OF RURAL NORTHERN CALIFORNIA AND REACH MEMBERS OF THE HOOPA, KARUK AND YUROK TRIBES. THE PROGRAM INCLUDES WATERSHED, FIRE AND FUELS, FISHERIES AND PLANTS EDUCATION INTERTWINED WITH TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE. LOCAL TEENS PARTICIPATE IN PAID SUMMER INTERNSHIPS INTRODUCING THEM TO JOBS IN FISHERIES, BOTANY AND FORESTRY. 22 CONSERVATION AND STEWARDSHIP EVENTS WILL INCLUDE FIELD TRIPS TO MONITOR SALMON POPULATIONS, RESTORATION OF RIPARIAN HABITAT, REMOVAL OF INVASIVE SPECIES, AND SUDDEN OAK DEATH BLITZES. ADDITIONALLY, 5 COMMUNITY GARDENS WILL BE BUILT TO ENCOURAGE THE USE OF LOCAL FOOD SYSTEMS, WHICH IS GREATLY NEEDED IN THE AREA, A USDA DESIGNATED FOOD DESERT WHERE RESIDENTS OFTEN TRAVEL 2 HOURS ROUND TRIP TO PURCHASE GROCERIES. CONSERVATION EFFORTS WILL PROVIDE QUALITY HABITAT FOR SALMON AND ACORNS, WHICH ARE CENTRAL TO NATIVE CULTURE AND THE LOCAL ECONOMY. OVERALL,

MERITO FOUNDATION'S BLUE-GREEN SCHOOLS PROJECT WILL ADVANCE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION AND STEWARDSHIP IN VENTURA COUNTY AND SANTA BARBARA COUNTY. MERITO FOUNDATION WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A CURRICULUM ON WATER RESOURCES, WATER QUALITY, AND CONSERVATION; PROVIDE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR TEACHERS; FACILITATE STUDENT FIELD EXPERIENCES; AND SUPPORT STUDENT-LED PROJECT PROPOSALS TO CONSERVE WATER AT SCHOOL CAMPUSES, PROTECT LOCAL WATERSHEDS, AND PROTECT AQUATIC ECOSYSTEMS. MERITO FOUNDATION WILL TRAIN 12 EDUCATORS AND REACH APPROXIMATELY 780-1000 STUDENTS.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $100,000.  PREAWARD COSTS ARE APPROVED BACK TO 7/1/2019.

THE INTER-TRIBAL COUNCIL OF ARIZONA SEEKS TO DEVELOP ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AMONG YOUTH IN 5 TRIBAL COMMUNITIES IN ARIZONA THROUGH CULTURALLY RELEVANT ACTIVITIES THAT PREPARE STUDENTS FOR ENVIRONMENTAL CAREERS. THE FIVE TRIBES THAT WILL BE REACHED ARE THE AK-CHIN INDIAN COMMUNITY, THE GILA RIVER INDIAN COMMUNITY, THE PASCUA YAQUI TRIBE, THE SAN CARLOS APACHE TRIBE AND THE TOHONO O'ODHAM NATION. THE PROJECT INCORPORATES TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL KNOWLEDGE AND FACILITATES INTERGENERATIONAL LEARNING TO TACKLE ISSUES SUCH AS PESTICIDE USE, SOLID WASTE, AIR AND WATER POLLUTION. THE PROJECT WILL BEGIN WITH A TRAINING FOR TEACHERS, ELDERS AND ENVIRONMENTAL PROFESSIONALS ON PROJECT BASED LEARNING AND AN INDIGENOUS ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION FRAMEWORK.  THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $100,000.  SEE TERMS AND CONDITIONS.  PREAWARD COSTS ARE AUTHORIZED BACK TO 9/1/2019.

THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE EDUCATION FOR STUDENTS AND ADULTS ABOUT THE RISKS OF CATASTROPHIC WILDFIRES AND HOW FUEL MANAGEMENT CAN HELP ADDRESS THIS ISSUE. THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA WILL HOST EDUCATIONAL YOUTH PROGRAMS AND TEACHER TRAININGS IN RURAL NORTHERN CALIFORNIA IN HOPLAND AND BROWNS VALLEY BY DEVELOPING A NEW CURRICULUM SPECIFICALLY ADAPTED FOR OAK WOODLAND ECOSYSTEMS.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $100,000.  SEE TERMS AND CONDITIONS.  PREAWARD COSTS HAVE BEEN APPROVED BACK TO JUNE 1, 2019.

PURPLE MAI'A FOUNDATION (PMF) WILL ADVANCE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION AND STEWARDSHIP IN HAWAII BY DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING CURRICULUM ON AQUATIC ECOSYSTEM SERVICES PROVIDED BY NATIVE HAWAIIAN FISHPONDS AND DEPLOYING LOW-COST SENSORS ALONGSIDE TRADITIONAL ECOLOGICAL PRACTICES. PMF WILL TRAIN EDUCATORS ON CURRICULUM IMPLEMENTATION AND USE SENSORS TO MEASURE FISHPOND CONDITIONS. IN ADDITION TO IN-CLASS INSTRUCTION, STUDENTS WILL PARTICIPATE IN EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING ACTIVITIES AT FISHPONDS.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $100,000.  SEE TERMS AND CONDITIONS.  PREAWARD COSTS HAVE BEEN APPROVED BACK TO 08/03/2018.

THIS FUNDING AGREEMENT WILL REACH APPROXIMATELY10,000 STUDENTS ACROSS 62 BAY AREA SCHOOLS IN TEACHING LOW-INCOME AND UNDERSERVED K-5 STUDENTS REGARDING SUSTAINABLE FOOD PRODUCTION, ALONG WITH RECYCLING PRACTICES, WATER CONSERVATION, ENERGY AUDITING, LUNCHROOM COMPOSTING, AND BIKE/WALK-TO-SCHOOL DAYS.  AS PART OF THEIR OUTDOOR CLASSROOM CURRICULUM, STUDENTS WILL LEARN TO GROW, HARVEST AND COOK FRESH PRODUCE USING SUSTAINABLE PRACTICES THAT WILL FORGE MEANINGFUL CONNECTIONS TO THE LOCAL ENVIRONMENT AND LIFE-LONG COMMITMENT TO PROTECTING SHARED RESOURCES.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $100,000.  SEE TERMS AND CONDITIONS.  PREAWARD COSTS HAVE BEEN APPROVED BACK TO AUGUST 1, 2018.

THE SEQUOIA RIVERLANDS TRUST (SRT) IS NON-PROFIT LAND TRUST BASED IN RURAL TULARE COUNTY WITHIN CALIFORNIA'S SAN JOAQUIN VALLEY WHICH SEEKS TO INSPIRE LOVE AND LASTING PROTECTION FOR IMPORTANT LANDS. SRT WILL ADVANCE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION AND STEWARDSHIP BY ENGAGING LANDOWNERS, FARMERS, CONSERVATIONISTS, BUSINESS PARTNERS AND GOVERNMENT AGENCIES IN TULARE, FRESNO, KERN, AND KINGS COUNTIES TO PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR LOCAL YOUTH AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO DEVELOP KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS TO PROTECT THEIR LOCAL ENVIRONMENT. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL HELP PRESERVE THE NATURAL AND AGRICULTURAL HERITAGE OF THE LOCAL AREA. SRT'S PROJECT WILL REACH UP TO:  600 STUDENTS; 60 INTERNS; 100 FARMERS/RANCHERS, TEACHERS/EDUCATORS, PARENTS, AND OTHER COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS; AND 300 VOLUNTEERS/COMMUNITY MEMBERS.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $85,239.  PREAWARD COSTS ARE APPROVED BACK TO 8/1/2018.

THE MALAMA LEARNING CENTER WILL ENGAGE STUDENTS, TEACHERS, AGRICULTURAL AND CONSERVATION PROFESSIONALS, AND THE COMMUNITY IN HANDS-ON LEARNING EXPERIENCES DESIGNED TO INSTILL INTEREST IN ENVIRONMENTAL STEM CAREERS AND CONSERVATION OF LOCAL NATURAL RESOURCES. THE GRANT WILL PROVIDE FOR CLASS FIELD TRIPS, RESEARCH PROJECTS, COMMUNITY SERVICE LEARNING DAYS, GREEN INSTITUTE SEMINARS, PRESENTATIONS AT MAJOR CONFERENCES AND TELEVISED PROGRAMS.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $80,000.  SEE TERMS AND CONDITIONS.

THE GRANT WILL SUPPORT FOUR SCHOOLS, EIGHT TEACHERS, AND 200 STUDENTS ON THE BIG ISLAND IN HAWAII IN HANDS-ON LEARNING IN SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING AND MATH (STEM) SUBJECTS THROUGH FIELD TRIPS, LAB EXPERIMENTS, AND FOREST CONSERVATION INTIATIVES. STUDENTS WILL LEARN ABOUT HOW NATIVE HAWAIIAN FORESTS HELP PROVIDE CLEAN DRINKING WATER, REDUCE THE RISK OF WILDFIRES, AND MINIMIZE EROSION.  THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $90,000. PREAWARD COSTS ARE APPROVED BACK TO 8/1/2017.

THE GRANTEE, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE NEVADA COUNTY SUPERINTENDENT OF SCHOOLS, WILL DEVELOP AN ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION CENTER AT THE WOOLMAN PROPERTY NEAR NEVADA CITY, CA TO SERVE AS A COUNTY-WIDE AND REGIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION RESOURCE FOR STUDENTS AND EDUCATIONAL TRAINING FOR TEACHERS. GRANTEE WILL ADAPT EXISTING ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION CURRICULUM TO REFLECT LOCAL ENVIRONMENTAL AND HISTORICAL CONCERNS INCLUDING LONG-TERM IMPACTS OF MINING AND EXTRACTIVE INDUSTRIES, THE ECOLOGICAL IMPORTANCE AND RESTORATION NEEDS OF THE LOCAL WATERSHED, AND THE HISTORY OF SURVIVAL AND ADAPTATION OF NATIVE AMERICAN TRIBES IN THE AREA. ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE TEAM BUILDING, POND STUDIES, RESTORATION AND INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL, AND PHENOLOGY. THE CURRICULUM WILL FOCUS ON RESTORING AND PROTECTING LOCAL WATERSHEDS, POND STUDIES, RESTORATION AND INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVEAL, AND PHENOLOGY.   THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $91,000.  SEE TERMS AND CONDITIONS.  PREAWARD C

DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO ORANGE COUNTY COASTKEEPER TO IMPLEMENT ITS PROJECT, WHICH WILL DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND DISSEMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PRACTICES, METHODS, AND TECHNIQUES, THAT WILL SERVE TO INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND ENCOURAGE BEHAVIOR THAT WILL BENEFIT THE ENVIRONMENT IN ORANGE COUNTY, CALIFORNIA. THE GRANTEE WILL EMPOWER STUDENTS WITH TOOLS AND RESOURCES TO BE ACTIVE PARTICIPANTS IN THE ENVIRONMENTAL MOVEMENT. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE STUDENTS A COMBINATION OF IN-CLASS LESSONS AND FIELD TRIPS TO THE UPPER NEWPORT BAY ECOLOGICAL RESERVE TO GAIN HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE LEARNING EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULA AND DEVELOPING SOLUTIONS TO CLIMATE CHANGE INDUCED PROBLEMS. STUDENTS WILL PARTICIPATE IN ONGOING WATER QUALITY AND ECOSYSTEM MONITORING, WHICH WILL PROVIDE CONNECTIONS BETWEEN CLASSROOM CONCEPTS AND REAL-WORLD ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES.

THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $98,491. PRE-AWARD COSTS HAVE BEEN APPROVED BACK TO 05/01/2023.

ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND KNOWLEDGE ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES IN ORANGE COUNTY, CALIFORNIA AND PROVIDE STUDENTS, TEACHERS, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS AND TO TAKE RESPONSIBLE ACTIONS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED DURING THIS PROJECT PERIOD INCLUDE: CLASSROOM LESSONS, FIELDS TRIPS, HANDS-ON LEARNING, OUTDOOR RECREATION, STEM EDUCATION, COMMUNITY ACTION PROJECTS, EDUCATOR TRAINING, AND COMMUNITY BUILDING.SUBRECIPIENT:ALL LISTED SUB-RECIPIENTS ARE NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS AS DESCRIBED IN SECTION 501(C)(3) OF THE
INTERNAL REVENUE CODE:
(1) ORANGE COUNTY ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE EDUCATION FUND
(2) BOLSA CHICA CONSERVANCY
(3) WETLANDS AND WILDLIFE CARE CENTER
(4) OC HABITATS
(5) PROJECT GROW
COASTKEEPER HAS A STRONG WORKING RELATIONSHIP WITH THE AFOREMENTIONED NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS
THROUGH OUR VARIOUS ONGOING PROGRAMS AND COMMUNITY RELATIONS. MANY DIRECTLY CONTRIBUTE TO OUR
EDUCATION PROGRAMS ON A REGULAR BASIS AND OFFER THEIR EXPERTISE IN REALMS OF CONSERVATION THAT
COMPLEMENT COASTKEEPER'S FOCUS ON WATER QUALITY AND CONSERVATION. ALL LISTED SUBRECIPIENTS WILL
CONTRIBUTE RESOURCES FOR CURRICULUM DEVELOPMENT, SUCH AS DATA OR MEDIA, OR STUDENT RESOURCES FOR COMMUNITY ACTION PROJECTS, SUCH AS VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES OR PROFESSIONAL NETWORKS.
COASTKEEPER WILL DIVIDE 25% OF THE TOTAL EPA FUNDS AWARDED FOR THIS PROGRAM EVENLY BY FIVE AND
DISTRIBUTE SUBAWARDS IN THE FORM OF A GRANT AT THE START OF THE PROJECT PERIOD.
OUTCOMES:IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE FOLLOWING DELIVERABLES:  THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO EMPOWER STUDENTS WITH TOOLS AND RESOURCES TO BE ACTIVE PARTICIPANTS IN THE ENVIRONMENTAL MOVEMENT. HISTORY SHOWS LOW-INCOME COMMUNITIES AND COMMUNITIES OF COLOR ARE DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFLICTED BY ENVIRONMENTAL INJUSTICES AND REPERCUSSIONS OF CLIMATE CHANGE. THESE SAME COMMUNITIES FACE SYSTEMIC BARRIERS THAT SUPPRESS EDUCATIONAL AND RECREATIONAL EXPERIENCES BY CREATING INEQUITABLE ACCESS TO NATURAL SPACES AND QUALITY STEM EDUCATION. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE STUDENTS A COMBINATION OF IN-CLASS LESSONS AND FIELD TRIPS TO THE UPPER NEWPORT BAY ECOLOGICAL RESERVE TO GAIN HANDS-ON EXPERIENCE LEARNING EVIDENCE-BASED CURRICULA AND DEVELOPING SOLUTIONS TO CLIMATE CHANGE INDUCED PROBLEMS. STUDENTS WILL PARTICIPATE IN ONGOING WATER QUALITY AND ECOSYSTEM MONITORING, WHICH WILL PROVIDE CONNECTIONS BETWEEN CLASSROOM CONCEPTS AND REAL-WORLD ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES. STUDENTS WILL APPLY THIS KNOWLEDGE BY ACTIVELY PARTICIPATING IN A COMMUNITY ACTION PROJECT AND ATTENDING A SYMPOSIUM WHERE THEY SHARE THEIR STEWARDSHIP PROJECTS WITH COMMUNITY MEMBERS. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO PRODUCE A CLIMATE-RESILIENCE CURRICULUM GUIDE AND PROVIDE EDUCATORS TRAINING TO CONTINUE EDUCATING STUDENTS BEYOND THE SCOPE OF THE PROGRAM AND BUILD A NETWORK OF ENGAGED LOCAL YOUTH AND TEACHERS.

DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO SEQUOIA RIVERLANDS TRUST TO IMPLEMENT ITS PROJECT, WHICH WILL DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND DISSEMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PRACTICES, METHODS, AND TECHNIQUES, THAT WILL SERVE TO INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND ENCOURAGE BEHAVIOR THAT WILL BENEFIT THE ENVIRONMENT IN VISALIA, CA. THE GRANTEE PROVIDES EXPOSURE BY RAISING INCREASING AWARENESS AND UNDERSTANDING OF ECOSYSTEM HEALTH AND MANAGEMENT. ANNUALLY, THIS PROGRAM ENGAGES 40-60 HIGH SCHOOL INTERNS FROM TULARE COUNTY. THE PROGRAM HAS EIGHT MODULES, EACH OF WHICH BUILDS ON THE LAST TO CREATE A COMPREHENSIVE VIEW OF REGIONAL ECOSYSTEMS. IN EACH MODULE, INTERNS PARTICIPATE IN A CLASSROOM SESSION, FOLLOWED BY A FIELD TRIP TO ONE OF SRT'S SEVEN NATURE PRESERVES TO APPLY WHAT THEY HAVE LEARNED. INTERNS WORK WITH FIELD PROFESSIONALS WHILE EXPLORING AND LEARNING ABOUT THE LAND AROUND THEM, COLLECTING DATA AND GAINING SKILLS NEEDED FOR FUTURE EMPLOYMENT. OVER A SINGLE YEAR, INTERNS TEACH AND ENGAGE WITH OVER 100 RANCHERS, FARMERS, PROFESSIONALS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND OVER 600 ELEMENTARY AND MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS AND TEACHERS FROM THE COUNTY. INTERNS CAN GAIN NEARLY 140 WORK-BASED LEARNING AND INTERNSHIP HOURS THROUGH THE PROGRAM. THROUGH THE EARTH ACADEMY PROGRAM, THESE INTERNS GAIN INSIGHT INTO THEIR LOCAL ENVIRONMENT, THE WORLD BEYOND, AND TOOLS NEEDED TO BECOME SUCCESSFUL COMMUNITY LEADERS AND ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDS.

DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO ARIZONA BOARD OF REGENTS - UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA TO IMPLEMENT ITS PROJECT, WHICH WILL DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND DISSEMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PRACTICES, METHODS, AND TECHNIQUES, THAT WILL SERVE TO INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND ENCOURAGE BEHAVIOR THAT WILL BENEFIT THE ENVIRONMENT THROUGHOUT ARIZONA. THE GRANTEE WILL DO THIS BY IMPLEMENTING A ROVING, INTERACTIVE EXHIBIT ON THE GROUNDWATER SYSTEM FOR UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY MEMBERS THAT INCLUDES PROFESSIONAL-DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITY FOR EDUCATORS FROM LOW-INCOME SCHOOLS.

THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $96,000.  PRE-AWARD COSTS ARE APPROVED BACK TO 5/1/2023.ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND KNOWLEDGE ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES THROUGHOUT ARIZONA AND PROVIDE STUDENTS, TEACHERS, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS AND TO TAKE RESPONSIBLE ACTIONS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED DURING THIS PROJECT PERIOD INCLUDE: IMPROVING GROUNDWATER QUALITY THROUGH A COMMUNITY EDUCATION PROJECT THAT WILL FEATURE A ROVING, INTERACTIVE EXHIBIT ON THE GROUNDWATER SYSTEM FOR UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY MEMBERS THAT INCLUDES PROFESSIONAL-DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITY FOR EDUCATORS FROM LOW-INCOME SCHOOLS. THE EXHIBIT WILL TRAVEL TO 12 UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, ONE PER MONTH. EACH VISIT WILL FEATURE A 'MOVIE-NIGHT' SHOWCASING NEWLY-DEVELOPED VIDEOS ON THE GROUNDWATER SYSTEM AND A GUEST SPEAKER TO DISCUSS SPECIFIC GROUNDWATER CONDITIONS IN THEIR COMMUNITY. EACH VISIT WILL INCLUDE INTERACTIVE COMPONENTS FOR ALL AGE GROUPS, INCLUDING A GROUNDWATER SYSTEM COLORING CONTEST. WINNING ENTRIES WILL BE ASSEMBLED INTO A FUN, FACT-FILLED 12-MONTH CALENDAR FOR PARTICIPANTS AND OTHERS. ATTENDANCE FOR EACH VISIT IS ESTIMATED AT 20-40 PEOPLE (240-480 TOTAL). ADDITIONALLY, THE TRAVELING EXHIBIT WILL PROVIDE ABOUT EDUCATORS WITH SEVERAL READY-TO-IMPLEMENT LESSONS ON THE GROUNDWATER SYSTEM. THESE EDUCATORS WILL HAVE AN OPPORTUNITY TO CHECK-OUT GROUNDWATER MODELS PART OF THE EXHIBIT WITH THEIR STUDENTS WHILE THE EXHIBIT IS ON DISPLAY. IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT 3-8 EDUCATORS PER LOCATION WILL RECEIVE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRAINING AND SHARE THEIR KNOWLEDGE WITH APPROXIMATELY 40-60 STUDENTS PER TEACHER, FOR A PROJECT TOTAL OF APPROXIMATELY 60 EDUCATORS FROM RURAL LOW-INCOME SCHOOLS WHO WILL PROVIDE INSTRUCTION TO ROUGHLY 2,400 - 3,600 K-12 STUDENTS.SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARDS WILL BE GIVEN TO ENTITIES TO PERFORM TASKS INTEGRAL TO THE PROJECT'S GOALS, AS OUTLINED BY THE PRIME. THE SUBAWARDS WILL GO TO NON-PROFIT COMMUNITY CENTERS AND SCHOOL DISTRICTS THROUGHOUT ARIZONA. THESE ORGANIZATIONS WILL HELP HOST UNIVERSITY OF ARIZONA'S ROVING WATER CONSERVATION EDUCATION EVENTS. OUTCOMES:IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE FOLLOWING DELIVERABLES: IMPROVING GROUNDWATER QUALITY THROUGH A COMMUNITY EDUCATION PROJECT THAT WILL FEATURE A ROVING, INTERACTIVE EXHIBIT ON THE GROUNDWATER SYSTEM FOR UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY MEMBERS THAT INCLUDES PROFESSIONAL-DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITY FOR EDUCATORS FROM LOW-INCOME SCHOOLS. EDUCATING THE PUBLIC ON GROUNDWATER IS OF PARAMOUNT IMPORTANCE FOR SEVERAL REASONS: 1) RURAL RESIDENTS ARE ALMOST ENTIRELY DEPENDENT ON GROUNDWATER, 2) ARIZONA DOES NOT REQUIRE PRIVATE WELL OWNERS TO TEST THE WATER QUALITY OF THEIR WELLS WHICH COULD IMPACT THEIR HEALTH; 3) CONDITIONS OF WATER OVERDRAFT ALREADY EXIST IN MANY RURAL AREAS; 4) MANY INDIVIDUALS IN ARIZONA DON'T UNDERSTAND HOW WATER WELLS FUNCTION, AND 5) INDIVIDUALS IN ARIZONA HAVE THE RIGHT TO KNOW WHERE THEIR DRINKING WATER COMES FROM AND HOW SAFE IT IS.

DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO ECORISE YOUTH INNOVATIONS TO IMPLEMENT ITS PROJECT, WHICH WILL DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND DISSEMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PRACTICES, METHODS, AND TECHNIQUES, THAT WILL SERVE TO INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND ENCOURAGE BEHAVIOR THAT WILL BENEFIT THE ENVIRONMENT IN PALM SPRINGS, SACRAMENTO, SAN FRANCISCO, AND SAN MATEO COUNTIES IN CALIFORNIA. THE GRANTEE WILL DO THIS BY TEACHING STUDENTS TO BUILD ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY; GAIN CONTEXT AROUND LOCAL ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS; AND LEARN HOW TO USE COMPASSION AND EMPATHY TO HELP REPAIR DAMAGE FROM RACIST BEHAVIORS, POLICIES, AND SYSTEMS. WITH THIS KNOWLEDGE AND AWARENESS, STUDENTS TAKE ACTION, IDENTIFYING AND DESIGNING SOLUTIONS THROUGH SELF-LED, INNOVATIVE PROJECTS THAT ENGAGE AND POSITIVELY IMPACT THE BROADER COMMUNITY. SUCH PROJECTS COULD INCLUDE SCHOOLWIDE WATER-CONSERVATION EFFORTS, SCHOOL AIR PURIFICATION INSTALLATIONS, THE CREATION OF OUTDOOR CLASSROOMS, AND MUCH MORE. THROUGH THIS COMBINATION OF LEARNING AND DOING, STUDENTS DEVELOP THEIR STEM AND 21ST CENTURY SKILLS, ACT AS LEADERS AND CREATIVE CHANGEMAKERS IN THEIR COMMUNITIES, AND ADVOCATE FOR A MORE JUST AND EQUITABLE CALIFORNIA.

THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDE FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $100,000.	ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND KNOWLEDGE ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES IN PALM SPRINGS, SACRAMENTO, SAN FRANCISCO, AND SAN MATEO COUNTIES IN CALIFORNIA AND PROVIDE STUDENTS AND TEACHERS THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS AND TO TAKE RESPONSIBLE ACTIONS. THIS PROJECT BRINGS OUR AWARD-WINNING CURRICULUM, PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT, AND SUPPORT TO 160 NEW TEACHERS IN URBAN AND RURAL REGIONS OF CALIFORNIA. THIS ACTION-ORIENTED PROGRAM INCLUDES 163 SUSTAINABLE INTELLIGENCE (S.I.) K-12 LESSONS, WHICH PROVIDE ECO-LITERACY ACROSS SEVEN THEMES (WATER, WASTE, ENERGY, FOOD, AIR, TRANSPORTATION, AND PUBLIC SPACES) IN ENGLISH AND SPANISH. IT INCLUDES 40 DESIGN STUDIO ACTIVITIES, WHICH GUIDE STUDENTS THROUGH AN ENGINEERING DESIGN PROCESS THEY CAN USE TO COME UP WITH INNOVATIVE SOLUTIONS TO PRESSING PROBLEMS. ALSO INCLUDED ARE THREE INTRODUCTION TO ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE MODULES, ONE EACH FOR ELEMENTARY, MIDDLE, AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS. TOGETHER, THIS CONTENT HELPS STUDENTS GAIN VALUABLE SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, ENGINEERING, AND MATH (STEM) SKILLS AS WELL AS ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE SOCIAL LITERACY AND PROJECT-BASED LEARNING SKILLS. EACH S.I. LESSON INCLUDES COMMUNITY CONNECTIONS, WHICH PROVIDE SUGGESTIONS FOR HOW BEST TO COLLABORATE WITH THE COMMUNITY ON IMPROVEMENT PROJECTS AND HELP STUDENTS SPREAD AWARENESS OF RELEVANT LOCAL ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES. AS STUDENTS COMPLETE ACTIVITIES AND AUDIT ENVIRONMENTAL CONDITIONS IN THEIR SCHOOLS AND COMMUNITIES, THEY ADDRESS EPA'S GOAL 2.2 BY LISTENING TO AND COLLABORATING WITH OTHER IMPACTED STAKEHOLDERS AND CREATING MEANINGFUL ENGAGEMENT. LESSONS ALSO PROVIDE CROSS-DISCIPLINARY CONNECTIONS, TECHNOLOGY EXTENSIONS, CULTURAL ADAPTATIONS, AND CORRELATIONS TO NATIONAL STANDARDS. DESCRIPTION:THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $60,000. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO INDUSTRY INITIATIVES FOR SCIENCE AND MATH EDUCATION TO IMPLEMENT ITS PROJECT, WHICH WILL DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND DISSEMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PRACTICES, METHODS, AND TECHNIQUES, THAT WILL SERVE TO INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND ENCOURAGE BEHAVIOR THAT WILL BENEFIT THE ENVIRONMENT IN SANTA CLARA, ALAMEDA, AND CONTRA COSTA COUNTIES IN THE BAY AREA, CALIFORNIA. THE GRANTEE WILL DO THIS BY HOSTING ONE-WEEK EXTERNSHIPS CONSISTING OF ENVIRONMENTAL AND EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES WITH OUR PARTNER BAYWORK AT WATER AGENCIES FOR LOCAL 6-12TH GRADE TEACHERS AT TITLE I SCHOOLS. DURING EACH DAY, TEACHERS MEET INDUSTRY PROFESSIONALS, TOUR WASTEWATER PLANTS, FRESHWATER RESERVOIRS, AND DAMS. THEY WILL WORK WITH A CURRICULUM COACH TO CREATE RELEVANT LESSON PLANS FOR THEIR CLASSROOMS THAT PREPARE STUDENTS TO TAKE RESPONSIBLE ACTIONS AROUND WATER RESOURCES AND BRING AWARENESS FOR WATER UTILITY CAREERS. TEACHERS HAVE THE UNIQUE ABILITY TO CHANGE THE TRAJECTORY OF THEIR STUDENTS' LIVES AND ARE APTLY POSITIONED TO INFLUENCE CAREER DECISIONS. THIS PROJECT WILL BETTER EQUIP THEM TO INSPIRE THEIR STUDENTS TO PURSUE WATER AND WASTEWATER CAREERS AND ULTIMATELY BECOME WATERSHED STEWARDS.ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND KNOWLEDGE ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES IN SANTA CLARA, ALAMEDA, AND CONTRA COSTA COUNTIES IN THE BAY AREA, CALIFORNIA AND PROVIDE STUDENTS AND TEACHERS THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS AND TO TAKE RESPONSIBLE ACTIONS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED DURING THIS PROJECT PERIOD INCLUDE: TWO 5-DAY WATER WEEK EXTERNSHIPS INTRODUCING TEACHERS TO WATER AND WASTEWATER CAREERS AND ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP PRACTICES, ADDITIONAL ONE DAY TEACHER WORKSHOPS, AND THE IMPLEMENTATION OF CURRICULUM AND YOUTH LEADERSHIP AND DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMS.  SUBRECIPIENT:OUR SUBAWARDS WILL GO TO THREE LOCAL 501(C)(3) NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS: THE KRAUSE CENTER FOR INNOVATION (KCI), A PART OF FOOTHILL COMMUNITY COLLEGE FOCUSED ON TEACHER EDUCATION, THE TECH INTERACTIVE, A SCIENCE MUSEUM, AND RESOURCE AREA FOR TEACHERS (RAFT), THE 'COSTCO' OF LOST-COST EDUCATOR SUPPLIES. WE HAVE BUDGETED FOR THREE FIXED AMOUNT SUBAWARDS TO BE FUNDED ON MILESTONE COMPLETION, FOR EXACTLY $5,000 EACH, ADDING UP TO EXACTLY 25% OF THE EPA FUNDS REQUESTED. THESE ORGANIZATIONS HAVE VERBALLY COMMITTED TO TASKS RELATED TO THE PROJECT FOR THE PROPOSED FUNDING AMOUNTS.OUTCOMES:IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE FOLLOWING DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THE PROJECT INCLUDE: THE MAIN SHORT-TERM OUTCOMES OF THESE ACTIVITIES ARE TO INCREASE STUDENTS' KNOWLEDGE OF THE IMPACT THEIR ACTIONS CAN HAVE ON THEIR LOCAL WATERSHED AND TO INCREASE THEIR AWARENESS OF WATER UTILITY CAREER PATHS. THE MEDIUM- AND LONG-TERM OUTCOMES ARE TO INSPIRE STUDENTS TO BECOME ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDS, POSSIBLY THROUGH A WATER UTILITY CAREER. THE OUTPUTS DELIVERED BY IGNITED, BAYWORK, AND THE SUBRECIPIENT NONPROFITS WILL EQUIP TEACHERS TO DEVELOP AND DELIVER LESSON PLANS. TEACHERS' LESSON PLANS AND CLASSROOM IMPLEMENTATION WILL ENABLE US TO REACH OUR EDUCATIONAL GOAL (CAREER DEVELOPMENT) BY FEATURING ONE OR MORE WATER UTILITY CAREERS IN THE LESSONS AND PROVIDING CONNECTIONS TO ROLE MODELS IN THESE FIELDS.

DESCRIPTION:THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES FULL FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $100,000. THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO EARTH TEAM TO IMPLEMENT ITS PROJECT, WHICH WILL DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND DISSEMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PRACTICES, METHODS, AND TECHNIQUES, THAT WILL SERVE TO INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND ENCOURAGE BEHAVIOR THAT WILL BENEFIT THE ENVIRONMENT IN RICHMOND, CA. THE GRANTEE WILL DO THIS BY EDUCATING STUDENTS ABOUT THEIR LOCAL WATERSHED, YOUTH LEADERSHIP, AND TEACHER TRAININGS.	ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND KNOWLEDGE ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES IN RICHMOND, CA AND PROVIDE STUDENTS, TEACHERS, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS AND TO TAKE RESPONSIBLE ACTIONS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED DURING THIS PROJECT PERIOD INCLUDE WATERSHED RESTORATION, FIELD TRIPS, YOUTH LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT, AND TEACHER TRAININGS.SUBRECIPIENT:FRIENDS OF MARSH CREEK, AMERICAN RIVERS, PITTSBURG HIGH SCHOOL, ANTIOCH HIGH SCHOOL,
FREEDOM/INDEPENDENCE HIGH SCHOOL. THESE ARE 5 PROJECT PARTNERS THAT WILL USE A $5,000
SUBAWARD EACH TO PAY PARTICIPATING STUDENT INTERNSHIP STIPENDS. THE INTERNSHIP ACTIVITIES ARE
EXCLUSIVELY ALIGNED WITH THE PROGRAM OBJECTIVES, ACTIVITIES, AND OUTCOMES AND EARTH TEAM
WILL TRACK THE PAYMENTS MADE TO THE 42 PARTICIPATING STUDENTS IN 3 TEAMS OF 14 EACH.OUTCOMES:IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE FOLLOWING DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THE PROJECT: SHORT-TERM OUTCOMES INCLUDE NEW KNOWLEDGE ABOUT WATERSHEDS, RESTORATION OF RIPARIAN HABITATS, MAINTENANCE OF THE FISH LADDERS, AND MONITORING THE SALMONID POPULATION IN THE MARSH CREEK WATERSHED. THE LONG-TERM OUTCOME IS TO RESTORE DECLINING SALMONID POPULATIONS STILL PRESENT IN THIS WATERSHED. STUDENTS WORK WITH EARTH TEAM STAFF AND EXPERT MENTORS TO LEARN HANDS-ON ALONG WITH A ROBUST NETWORK OF LOCAL COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS, MUNICIPAL AND COUNTY AGENCIES. THEY ACQUIRE SCIENTIFIC AND MONITORING SKILLS INCLUDING WATER AND SOIL QUALITY TESTING, LITTER ASSESSMENTS, MAPPING AND REMOVAL TO PREVENT BLOCKING THE FISH LADDER, AND MORE. MEASURABLE CHANGES IN STEWARDSHIP ATTITUDES ARE REACHED WITHIN THE PROJECT PERIOD AMONG CAMPUS PEERS AND FAMILIES THROUGH PRESENTATIONS AND SURVEYS AT EDUCATIONAL EVENTS. INDIVIDUAL AND CAMPUS-WIDE BEHAVIOR CHANGES ARE ALSO EXPECTED DURING THE PROJECT PERIOD WITH REDUCTION OF PLASTIC LITTER POLLUTING THE CREEK, AND REDUCED USED OF HOUSEHOLD HARSH CHEMICALS AND GARDEN PESTICIDES.

THE FOUNDATION FOR SANTA BARBARA CITY COLLEGE WILL DEVELOP A NETWORK OF EDUCATIONAL PERMACULTURE GARDEN SITES ACROSS SANTA BARBARA, ENGAGING K-14 STUDENTS AND TEACHERS, AND THE PUBLIC AROUND THE ECOLOGICAL, HEALTH, AND WATER CONSERVATION BENEFITS OF NATIVE HABITAT, FOOD-PRODUCING GARDENS. THEY ANTICIPATE THIS PROJECT REACHING OVER 34,000 PARTICIPANTS THROUGH COURSES AT SANTA BARBARA CITY COLLEGE AND IN K-12 SCHOOLS, COMMUNITY ACTIONS, PARTNER ACTIVITIES, AND PUBLIC EVENTS, WITH THE POTENTIAL FOR THOUSANDS MORE THROUGH ONLINE RESOURCES AND THOSE FED BY THE FOODS PRODUCED AT THE GARDENS OVER ONE-THIRD OF THE SANTA BARBARA AREA.   THIS AGREEMENT PROVIDES FEDERAL FUNDING IN THE AMOUNT OF $99,945.

EARTH ACADEMY INCLUDES PROJECT-BASED LEARNING USING HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES/LESSONS; FIELD TRIPS TO NATURE SITES; SERVICE-LEARNING OPEN TO STUDENTS AND THE PUBLIC; PRESENTATIONS TO STUDENTS, FARMERS/RANCHERS, AND STAKEHOLDERS; AND COMMUNITY EVENTS. DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO KANSAS CITY COMMUNITY GARDENS (KCCG) TO DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND DISSEMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PRACTICES, METHODS, AND TECHNIQUES IN THE KANSAS CITY AREA. THE GRANTEE WILL ENGAGE WITH ELEMENTARY AND SECONDARY STUDENTS TO LEARN ABOUT HOW: PLANTING AND MAINTAINING TREES REDUCES THE HEAT ISLAND EFFECT, CONSUMING LOCAL FOOD REDUCES EMISSIONS, AND MANAGING WITH NATURAL HORTICULTURAL PRODUCTS AND METHODS (SUCH AS INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT) ELIMINATES HARMFUL CHEMICAL RUNOFF. ACTIVITIES:KCCG WILL DEVELOP AND DELIVER TEACHER ACTIVITY GUIDES, INSTRUCTIONAL VIDEOS, AND TRAINING WORKSHOPS ABOUT THE ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS ORCHARDS PROVIDE. 
SUBRECIPIENT:KCCG WILL PROVIDE SUBAWARDS TO SCHOOLS FOR HIGH-QUALITY ORCHARD TOOLS TO SCHOOLS IN NEED AND SHOW THEM HOW TO USE THEIR NEW TOOLS. TOOLS MAY INCLUDE: HAND PRUNERS, PRUNING SAWS, LOPPERS, ORCHARD LADDERS, BACKPACK SPRAYERS, FRUIT POLE PICKERS, POLE PRUNERS, PLASTIC TREE BAFFLES, FORKS AND SHOVELS AND WHEELBARROWS. TEACHERS, STUDENTS, AND COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERS WILL LEARN HANDS-ON CARE OF SCHOOL ORCHARDS THROUGH TASKS, SUCH AS WATERING, MULCHING, BLOSSOM PINCHING, FRUIT THINNING, SPRAYING, AND PRUNING. WHILE PARTICIPATING IN THESE ACTIVITIES, STUDENTS WILL LEARN ABOUT TOPICS, INCLUDING: NUTRITION, ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS OF TREES, SOIL BIOLOGY, AND TREE BIOLOGY. OUTCOMES:EXPECTED DELIVERABLE AND OUTCOMES INCLUDE: 1) TEACHERS WILL BE EQUIPPED WITH RESOURCES TO LEAD STUDENTS IN EXPERIENTIAL ENVIRONMENTAL LEARNING IN THE SCHOOL ORCHARD. 2) STUDENTS WILL INCREASE THEIR ENVIRONMENTAL KNOWLEDGE BY PARTICIPATING IN HANDS-ON CARE OF THEIR SCHOOL ORCHARD. 3) ADULT VOLUNTEERS FROM THE SCHOOL COMMUNITY WILL INCREASE THEIR ENVIRONMENTAL KNOWLEDGE AND PARTICIPATE IN CARE OF ORCHARD TREES. THE COMBINED EFFECT OF THESE ACTIONS WILL RESULT IN PARTICIPANTS UNDERSTANDING THEIR ORCHARD'S IMPACT ON CLIMATE CHANGE, AIR QUALITY, AND WATER QUALITY OVER THE SPAN OF MANY YEARS, LEADING TO MORE INFORMED CHOICES AND ACTIONS. INTENDED BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE STUDENTS, TEACHERS, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN THE KANSAS CITY AREA.

DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO SOUTH CENTRAL OZARK COUNCIL OF GOVERNMENTS TO DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND DISSEMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PRACTICES, METHODS, AND TECHNIQUES, THAT WILL INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND ENCOURAGE BEHAVIOR THAT WILL BENEFIT THE ENVIRONMENT IN DOUGLAS, HOWELL, OREGON, OZARK, SHANNON, TEXAS, AND WRIGHT COUNTIES (MISSOURI OZARKS). THE GRANTEE WILL OFFER PUBLIC SCHOOL EDUCATORS WORKSHOPS AND TEACHING TOOLS ABOUT WATERSHEDS, GROUNDWATER, WATER QUALITY, WATER USE, CONSERVATION, STEWARDSHIP, CAVES, SPRINGS, AND HOW HUMAN ACTIONS AND DECISIONS AFFECT WATER.ACTIVITIES:ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED INCLUDE; DEVELOPING AND DELIVERING HANDS-ON EDUCATOR WORKSHOPS, FIELD TRIPS, AND TEACHER SUPPORT ON WATERSHED AND KARST EDUCATION. SUBRECIPIENT:FIVE SUBAWARDS OF $5,000.00 EACH ($25,000 TOTAL) WILL BE PROVIDED TO SCHOOL DISTRICTS WHOSE TEACHERS PARTICIPATED IN THE EDUCATOR WORKSHOPS AND/OR NONPROFITS IN THE SEVEN-COUNTY AREA. SUBAWARDEES WILL BE ABLE TO FUND 5-8 STUDENT OZARK KARST FIELD TRIPS TO REINFORCE LEARNING AND CONNECT STUDENTS TO THEIR WATERSHEDS. THE SUBAWARD FUNDING MAY BE USED BY THE SCHOOLS TO PAY FOR RELATED EXPENSES, SUCH AS: SCHOOL BUS FUEL, BUS DRIVER'S WAGES, LUNCH COSTS AND DRINKING WATER FOR STUDENTS, COSTS FOR SUBSTITUTE TEACHERS, STUDENTS' PROTECTIVE GEAR, SUPPLIES (LIKE BAGS FOR COLLECTING FOUND TRASH), AND ANY ENTRANCE OR GUIDE FEES.OUTCOMES:DELIVERABLES INCLUDE A FREE PROFESSIONALLY FILMED VIDEO OF THE TEACHERS' WORKSHOPS AND FIELD TRIPS, CURRICULA, HANDS-ON DEMONSTRATION MATERIALS, CRITICAL THINKING GAMES, AND DOCUMENTARY VIDEOS FOR USE IN CLASSROOMS. EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THE PROJECT INCLUDE: SHORT-TERM - 50 EDUCATORS WILL BE TRAINED AND PROVIDED KARST-SPECIFIC WATER QUALITY EDUCATION RESOURCES TO USE WITH STUDENTS. MID-TERM - MANY 4-12 GRADE STUDENTS IN THE MISSOURI OZARKS WILL HAVE INCREASED UNDERSTANDING OF WATERSHEDS, KARST, AND WATER QUALITY. LONG-TERM - OZARK YOUTH WILL SHARE KNOWLEDGE WITH THEIR FRIENDS AND FAMILIES, AND MAKE DECISIONS THAT PROTECT WATER QUALITY. THIS WILL BENEFIT WATER QUALITY AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES THROUGHOUT THE MISSOURI OZARKS.

DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO KANSAS ASSOCIATION FOR CONSERVATION AND ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION (KACEE) TO DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND DISSEMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PRACTICES, METHODS, AND TECHNIQUES WITHIN KANSAS, MISSOURI AND NEBRASKA. THE GRANTEE WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE NEBRASKA ALLIANCE FOR CONSERVATION AND AND ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION (NACEE) AND THE MISSOURI ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION ASSOCIATION (MEEA) TO DEVELOP A SYSTEM WHICH EFFECTIVELY AND EFFICIENTLY DELIVERS AND SUSTAINS COMPREHENSIVE EE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR EDUCATORS. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, KACEE AIMS TO PREPARE FORMAL AND NON-FORMAL EDUCATORS TO ADDRESS CLIMATE CHANGE AND WASTE WITH THEIR LEARNERS. THIS PROJECT WILL INITIALLY TARGET 100 EDUCATORS. ACTIVITIES: ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED DURING THIS PROJECT PERIOD INCLUDE: (1) CREATE A PROJECT LEADERSHIP TEAM FOR THE PROJECT TO DESIGN AND FACILITATE A NEEDS ASSESSMENT WITH KEY STAKEHOLDERS TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT NEEDS OF THE REGION AND EACH INDIVIDUAL STATE AROUND CLIMATE CHANGE AND AIR QUALITY EDUCATION. (2) DEVELOP CONTENT FOR TWO NEW SHARED ONLINE COURSES THAT WILL SUPPORT EDUCATORS IN ADDRESSING CLIMATE CHANGE AND IMPROVING AIR QUALITY, INCLUDING ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE. (3) ESTABLISH A SHARED ONLINE LEARNING MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (LMS) PLATFORM FOR THE REGION. (4) TEN COURSE PARTICIPANTS WILL COMPLETE A CAPSTONE PROJECT TO IMPLEMENT SKILLS LEARNED IN ADDRESSING CLIMATE CHANGE AND IMPROVING AIR QUALITY AND A SECOND COURSE ADDRESSING WASTE REDUCTION. (5) COMPILE AND SHARE THE RESULTS OF THE CAPSTONE PROJECTS OF PILOT TO ENCOURAGE FURTHER DEVELOPMENT OF COMMUNITY-BASED PROJECTS TO ADDRESS CLIMATE CHANGE AND AIR QUALITY OR REVITALIZE LAND AND PREVENT CONTAMINATION THROUGHOUT THE STATE AND REGION. 
 SUBRECIPIENT:SUBAWARD ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: IMPLEMENTING EECREDENTIAL COURSES IN MISSOURI AND NEBRASKA, MARKETING, LOGISTIC MANAGEMENT, ENROLLING EDUCATORS, FACILITATING, MODERATING AND EVALUATING COURSES. 


OUTCOMES:IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE FOLLOWING DELIVERABLES: BUILDING CAPACITY FOR STATE EE ORGANIZATIONS TO MORE EFFECTIVELY AND EFFICIENTLY DELIVER HIGH QUALITY PROFESSIONAL LEARNING, BUILDING THE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS OF EDUCATORS TO PROVIDE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION TO PRE K-12 STUDENTS. ALSO INCREASE THE MASTERY AND PROFESSIONALIZATION OF EDUCATORS TO EFFECTIVELY DELIVER ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION THROUGH EECREDENTIALS.

TEAMS OF FORMAL AND INFORMAL ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATORS IN OUR THREE STATES WHO MEET OUR SELECTION CRITERIA WILL BE INVITED TO APPLY FOR THE PROGRAM. THESE CRITERIA INCLUDE EDUCATORS WHO PROVIDE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION TO UNDERSERVED AUDIENCES.

PROJECT GOALS INCLUDE MAINTAINING, DIVERSIFYING, AND EXPANDING EE PROGRAMS AVAILABLE TO UNDERSERVED YOUTH WITHIN THE SAN LUIS VALLEY THAT ADDRESS AGRICULTURAL EDUCATION, WATERSHED HEALTH, AND CONSERVATION STEWARDSHIP. THESE PROJECTS INCLUDE PROGRAMS SUCH AS SUMMER YOUTH CAMPS, RIVER RESTORATION, NATURAL RESOURCE WORKSHOPS, AND CLASS TO FIELD EXPERIENCES TO EDUCATE AND INSPIRE LOCAL YOUTH TO GET INVOLVED WITH NATURAL RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP. WITH THE PARTNERS, THEY WILL WORK ON EXPANDING CONSERVATION DAYS, CO-HOST WATER FEST ON THE RIO FOR STUDENTS AND PROVIDE STREAMBANK RESTORATION AND WATER QUALITY PROJECTS FOR YOUTH.

THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE AUTHENTIC SUMMER ENVIRONMENTAL RESEARCH EXPERIENCES FOR TWELVE STUDENTS IN TARGETED SCHOOL DISTRICTS. TEACHERS WILL BE MENTORED ON COMMUNITY PROJECT DEVELOPMENT ADDRESSING ISSUES OF SAFE AND CLEAN WATER AND LAND REVITALIZATION. THE PROGRAM WILL USE THE OUTDOOR LABORATORY OF BUTTE, MONTANA'S SUPERFUND SITE TO ILLUSTRATE METHODS FOR BOTH TEACHERS AND STUDENTS ON WATER QUALITY MONITORING, STORMWATER MANAGEMENT, SOIL REMEDIATION, AND CLIMATE RESILIENCY. THROUGH THE USE OF COMMUNITY PROJECTS, THE PROGRAM ENGAGES TEACHERS AND STUDENTS, AS WELL AS THE GENERAL PUBLIC, IN STEWARDSHIP AND EDUCATION OF THEIR LOCAL ENVIRONMENT AND ISSUES.

THE PROJECT HAS FOUR GOALS: 1. INCREASE AWARENESS ABOUT CAREERS IN ENVIRONMENTAL FIELDS FOR HIGH SCHOOL YOUTH; 2. INCREASE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS OF HIGH SCHOOL YOUTH ABOUT THE TYPES OF ENVIRONMENTAL CAREERS AND THE EDUCATION AND TRAINING NEEDED TO PURSUE THEM; 3. INCREASE THE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS OF YOUTH CAREER MENTORS IN SUPPORTING YOUTH IN PURSUING A CAREER IN AN ENVIRONMENTAL FIELD; AND 4. INCREASE PARTICIPATION OF YOUTH AND COMMUNITY COLLABORATION IN ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES.

THE PROJECT GOALS ARE TO INCREASE MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS' ABILITIES TO MAKE EVIDENCE-BASED DECISIONS ABOUT LOCAL WILDLIFE CONSERVATION THROUGH ANALYSIS OF AUTHENTIC WILDLIFE PHOTOGRAPHIC DATA. IT WILL PROVIDE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO MIDDLE SCHOOL TEACHERS ON HOW TO USE CAMERA TRAPS, INTERPRET AND ANALYZE DATA, IDENTIFY OTHER LOCALLY RELEVANT SOCIAL ECOLOGICAL DATA, AND USE WRITING-TO-LEARN TOOLS TO FACILITATE STUDENT PROBLEM-SOLVING.  THE PROJECT WILL MEASURE STUDENTS' ABILITIES TO CONSTRUCT EVIDENCE-BASED ARGUMENTS ABOUT CONSERVATION BEFORE AND AFTER OUR PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT INTERVENTION.

THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO FACILITATE STUDENT EXPERIENCES THAT INCREASE PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING AROUND LOCAL AQUATIC HEALTH AND WATER QUALITY. THEY WILL ACCOMPLISH THESE OBJECTIVES THROUGH CURRICULA DEVELOPMENT WORKSHOPS, FIELD-BASED DATA COLLECTION EVENTS, ANALYSIS, AND STUDENT LED PRESENTATION OF THEIR RESULTS TO THEIR COMMUNITY. THE LATTER WILL BE ADAPTIVE BASED ON STUDENT FINDINGS AND WILL TAKE THE FORM OF COMMUNITY CONFERENCES, TRAILHEAD BROCHURES, AND INTERACTIVE MAPS.

IN THIS PROJECT THE NATIONAL CENTER FOR APPRORIATE TECHNOLOGY WILL WORK IN THE STATE OF MONTANA WITH SIX COMMUNITIES, LOCAL FARMERS, AND RANCHERS TO EDUCATE STUDENTS ABOUT THE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS OF FOOD PRODUCTION.

THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS ABOUT THE NEED FOR OUTDOOR WATER CONSERVATION IN UTAH AND WILL PROVIDE PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS WITH THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO DESIGN, INSTALL, AND MAINTAIN A LANDSCAPE APPROPRIATE FOR UTAH'S CLIMATE. EDUCATION EFFORTS WILL BE CONDUCTED IN BOTH FORMAL AND INFORMAL SETTINGS AND WILL LEAD TO INCREASED ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP BY UTAH RESIDENTS. PROGRAM OBJECTIVES WILL BE MET AS PROJECT ACTIVITIES LEAD UTAHNS THROUGH THE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION CONTINUUM TOWARDS IMPROVED ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP.

NATIONAL WILDLIFE FEDERATION WILL CONDUCT SIX PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT WORKSHOPS FOR A VARIETY OF SCHOOL STAKEHOLDERS AND SUPPORT 15 SEED GRANT ACTION PROJECTS USING THE WATER PATHWAY. TEACHERS WILL USE ACTIVITIES FROM PROJECT WET TO PROMOTE AWARENESS OF WATER USAGE AS STUDENTS CALCULATE THEIR WATER FOOTPRINT. THE FRAMEWORK PROVIDES TEACHERS A STRUCTURE FOR LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES; IT ALLOWS SCHOOLS TO USE THEIR GROUNDS, BUILDINGS AND CURRICULUM AS AN AUTHENTIC LEARNING LABORATORY, WHERE STUDENTS CAN EXPERIENCE REAL-LIFE ISSUES IN THEIR CLASSROOM AND OUTDOOR LEARNING.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO HAVE AN EMPOWERED, INFORMED, CAPABLE AND RESPONSIBLE CADRE OF YOUTH AND ADULT CITIZEN SCIENTISTS WHO ARE ENGAGED IN PROGRAMS THAT PROMOTE ENVIRONMENTAL AND CONSERVATION STEWARDSHIP. THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE EVENTS SUCH AS MIGRATORY BIRD CELEBRATIONS AND WYOMING CITIZEN SCIENCE.  EDUCATORS WILL BE TRAINED TO ENGAGE YOUTH IN CITIZEN SCIENCE ACTIVITIES. HOST HABITAT HERO WORKSHOPS, PRESENTATIONS, WILDSCAPE AMBASSADOR TRAININGS, TABLING OUTREACH AND EVENTS WILL ENGAGE 4,000 COMMUNITY MEMBERS ON THE IMPORTANCE ON CREATING BIRDFRIENDLY GARDENS.

SCAPE 2 INCREASES PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES AND PROVIDES STUDENTS AND TEACHERS THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS AND TO TAKE RESPONSIBLE ACTIONS. THE PROJECT ADDRESSES THE WHOLE OF THE EE CONTINUUM FROM AWARENESS TO STEWARDSHIP, THROUGH THE FOLLOWING GOALS: CONNECT LOCAL DATA TO SYSTEM KNOWLEDGE, EXPERIENCE BEHAVIORAL CHANGES THROUGH NON-REGULATORY MEANS, USE DIGITAL TOOLS AND CONDUCT FIELD RESEARCH, INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY, IMPLEMENT CAREER DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES AND CATALYZE PUBLIC PARTICIPATION AND COMMUNITY COLLABORATION.

THIS PROJECT INVOLVES THE USE OF A MOBILE S.T.E.M. LAB TO INTRODUCE MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS TO VITAL ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES AROUND COLORADO WATER SUPPLIES. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE STUDENT AND TEACHER UNDERSTANDING OF THE IMPORTANCE OF HYDROLOGICAL SYSTEMS IN THEIR COMMUNITY AND HOW THESE HYDROLOGICAL SYSTEMS FIT INTO THE GLOBAL PICTURE. IT WILL ALSO PROMOTE ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP AND INCREASE STUDENT'S CAPACITY FOR INFORMED DECISION-MAKING ABOUT WATER ISSUES BOTH ON A LOCAL AND GLOBAL SCALE.
THIS PROJECT WILL MAKE LYONS, COLORADO THE FIRST ZERO WASTE TOWN IN THE COUNTRY BY EDUCATING EVERY RESIDENT ABOUT WASTE ISSUES AND ZERO WASTE PRACTIC

DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO THE PROPOSED 'CLIMATE CHANGEMAKERS' PROJECT--A MEANINGFUL WATERSHED EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE (MWEE)--THAT PLANS TO CONNECT 3RD GRADE STUDENTS TO THEIR ENVIRONMENT BY BUILDING AWARENESS OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND CHALLENGING THEM TO THINK ABOUT HOW THE LOCAL COMMUNITY'S BUILT AND NATURAL ENVIRONMENTS CONTRIBUTE TO WARMING TEMPERATURES IN BALTIMORE CITY AND THE DESIGNATION OF THEIR NEIGHBORHOODS AS 'URBAN HEAT ISLANDS.' STUDENTS WILL BE EMPOWERED TO USE THIS KNOWLEDGE TO BRAINSTORM AND IMPLEMENT VARIOUS STEWARDSHIP ACTION PROJECTS THAT WILL REDUCE THE AMOUNT OF HEAT EMITTED FROM THEIR SCHOOLYARDS, BUILD ENVIRONMENTS AND INCREASE THEIR COMMUNITIES' CLIMATE RESILIENCY. STUDENTS WILL REFLECT ON THE EFFICACY OF THEIR SOLUTIONS AND WHY IT IS SO IMPORTANT TO CONTINUE TO TAKE THESE ACTIONS AS LIFELONG ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT'S KNOWLEDGE BUILDING, PROBLEM SOLVING, AND ACTION PROJECTS ADDRESS THE EPA-EE CONTINUUM FROM AWARENESS TO STEWARDSHIP, WITH CLEARLY DEFINED STEPS THAT ENGAGE CHILDREN AND TEACH CRITICAL THINKING, COLLABORATION, AND DECISION-MAKING. PROGRAMMING INCLUDES FORMAL AND INFORMAL LEARNING AND TAKES PLACE BOTH IN THE CLASSROOM AND OUTDOORS, WHERE STUDENTS CONDUCT ACTIVITIES THAT DIRECTLY AND IMMEDIATELY AFFECT THE ENVIRONMENT. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROPOSED COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS WILL PROVIDE INFORMAL LEARNING FOR ALL AGES THROUGH INTERACTIVE STEWARDSHIP PROJECTS DESIGNED TO REDUCE LOCAL TEMPERATURES AND ENCOURAGE LIFELONG STEWARDSHIP.ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND KNOWLEDGE ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES IN BALTIMORE, MD. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL TAKE PLACE IN BALTIMORE CITY, SPECIFICALLY THE SOUTH BALTIMORE NEIGHBORHOODS OF BROOKLYN, CURTIS BAY, AND WESTPORT. PROGRAM ACTIVITIES WILL OCCUR AT FOUR TITLE I SOUTH BALTIMORE PUBLIC ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS/SCHOOLYARDS (CURTIS BAY ELEMENTARY, BAY BROOK ELEMENTARY/MIDDLE, WESTPORT ACADEMY, AND MAREE G. FARRING ELEMENTARY/MIDDLE) AND THE MASONVILLE COVE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION CAMPUS (MC). THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL EDUCATE STUDENTS ABOUT HOW CLIMATE CHANGE IS EXACERBATING THE HEAT ISLAND EFFECT IN THEIR NEIGHBORHOODS, AND WHAT THEY CAN DO TO BE PART OF A SOLUTION, INCLUDING DIRECT ACTION (PLANTINGS, REDUCTION OF HEAT-ATTRACTING SURFACES) AND DEVELOPMENT OF SUSTAINED STEWARDSHIP. THEY WILL ALSO TEACH THEM TO BE COMMUNITY ADVOCATES THROUGH ACTIONS SUCH AS LETTER WRITING TO ELECTED OFFICIALS PROPOSING CHANGES SUCH AS INCREASED TREE COVER, REMOVAL OF ASPHALT, OR PAINTING ROOFS LIGHT COLORS; OR TO BALTIMORE CITY PUBLIC SCHOOLS (BCPS) OFFICIALS REGARDING THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN HEAT ISLANDS AND THE LACK OF AIR-CONDITIONED SCHOOLS; AND THE CREATION OF PUBLIC SERVICE ANNOUNCEMENTS THAT CREATIVELY EXPLAIN CLIMATE CHANGE AND ITS DIRE CONSEQUENCES.
SUBRECIPIENT:LCF PLANS TO SUBGRANT TO THE NATIONAL AQUARIUM, THE BALTIMORE COMMUNITY TOOLBANK, AND CLEARSHARK H20. THEY WILL ALSO APPROACH THE BALTIMORE TREE TRUST AND THE HARBOR CITY.  ALL OF THESE ORGANIZATIONS ARE ELIGIBLE 501(C)(3) NON-PROFITS; THEY ARE PLANNING ON CHOOSING 4 SUBGRANTEES. TO ENSURE THAT THEY WILL AWARD EXACTLY 25% OF OUR GRANT IN AWARDS OF $5,000 OR LESS ($18,750 OF OUR $75,000 ASK), WE WILL GIVE 3 SUBGRANTS OF $5,000 EACH, AND ONE SUBGRANT OF $3,750.
.OUTCOMES:THIS PROJECT WILL SERVE 300 3RD GRADE STUDENTS AND EIGHT TEACHERS FROM FOUR BALTIMORE CITY PUBLIC SCHOOL/TITLE I SCHOOLSMDASH;BAY BROOK ELEMENTARY/MIDDLE, CURTIS BAY ELEMENTARY, WESTPORT ACADEMY, AND MAREE G. FARRING ELEMENTARY/MIDDLE, AS WELL AS NEIGHBORHOOD RESIDENTS OF ALL AGES WITH COMMUNITY PROGRAMS. DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO THE TRUST FOR PUBLIC LAND TO DELIVER ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION THROUGH STEWARDSHIP OF PHILADELPHIA GREEN SCHOOLYARDS. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO CREATE SITE-SPECIFIC PROGRAMS TO EDUCATE STUDENTS AND NEIGHBORS ABOUT THEIR LOCAL ENVIRONMENT THROUGH THE HANDS-ON CARE OF FIVE RECENTLY INSTALLED GREEN SCHOOLYARDS. THE PROJECT WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH FIVE SCHOOLS, AND COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS LINKED TO THOSE SCHOOLS, TO DEVELOP LONG-LASTING PROGRAMS FOCUSED ON EDUCATING ELEMENTARY AND MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS ABOUT THE LOCAL ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES THAT ARE MITIGATED THROUGH SCHOOLYARD GREEN SPACES AND GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE. THE PROJECTS WILL LEAD TO A WIDER AWARENESS AND KNOWLEDGE OF THE ENVIRONMENT THROUGH LESSONS AND FIELD TRIPS. TPL WILL IMPLEMENT ITS PROJECT, WHICH WILL DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND DISSEMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PRACTICES, METHODS, AND TECHNIQUES, THAT WILL SERVE TO INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND ENCOURAGE BEHAVIOR THAT WILL BENEFIT THE ENVIRONMENT IN PHILADELPHIA, PA. THE FIVE SCHOOLS SELECTED ARE: WILLIAM CRAMP, SOUTHWARK, ADD B. ANDERSON, ALEXANDER ADAIRE, AND JAMES R. LOWELL. ALL OF THESE ARE TITLE I SCHOOLS WITH RACIALLY DIVERSE STUDENT BODIES, SOME OF WHOM ARE ALSO ENGLISH-LEARNERS (EL) AND A MAJORITY OF WHOM ARE ALSO ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED. TWO OF THESE SCHOOLS, CRAMP AND SOUTHWARK, ARE COMMUNITY SCHOOLS, A PARTNERSHIP WITH THE CITY OF PHILADELPHIA.ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND KNOWLEDGE ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES IN PHILADELPHIA AND PROVIDE THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS AND TO TAKE RESPONSIBLE ACTIONS.  THIS PROGRAM WILL SERVE FIVE SCHOOLS IN TPL'S COMMUNITY SCHOOLYARDS INITIATIVE, AND THEIR SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES IN NORTH PHILADELPHIA, SOUTH PHILADELPHIA, COBBS CREEK, AND FISHTOWN. EACH OF THESE SCHOOLYARDS HAVE VARYING STEWARDSHIP NEEDS THAT COULD BE MET WITH GREATER RESOURCES AND INVOLVEMENT. THE PROJECT WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH THE FIVE SCHOOLS, AND COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS LINKED TO THOSE SCHOOLS, TO DEVELOP LONG-LASTING PROGRAMS FOCUSED ON EDUCATING ELEMENTARY AND MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS ABOUT THE LOCAL ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES THAT ARE MITIGATED THROUGH SCHOOLYARD GREEN SPACES AND GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE. IN TOTAL, THESE SCHOOLYARDS SERVE 75,459 RESIDENTS, MANY OF WHOM ARE LOW-INCOME, LIVING WITHIN A TEN-MINUTE WALK.SUBRECIPIENT:TPL WILL USE EXISTING METHODS AND INTERNAL CHANNELS TO ENSURE THAT EXACTLY 25 PERCENT OF AWARDED EPA

THEIR TASKS, RESPONSIBILITIES, AS WELL AS METHODS AND SPECIFIC TIMELINES FOR REPORTING SPENDING, EVALUATION,
AND PROGRESS TO TPL.OUTCOMES:IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE FOLLOWING DELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES:  5 INDIVIDUAL STUDENT-MADE STEWARDSHIP GUIDES; AT LEAST 1 FIELD TRIP OR GUEST VISIT FOR EACH SCHOOL (5 TOTAL) IN CLASSES OR GROUPS OF UP TO 30 STUDENTS; 1 STUDENT-LED PUBLIC COMMUNITY VOLUNTEER DAY AT EACH SCHOOL (5 TOTAL); PLANS FOR LONG TERM COMMUNITY AND STUDENT-LED STEWARDSHIP OF 5 SCHOOLYARDS. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE HEALTHY AND FUNCTIONAL SHADE TREES AND GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE AT 5 SCHOOLYARDS. STUDENTS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS WILL HAVE INCREASED AWARENESS ABOUT WATER-RELATED ISSUES, CLIMATE CHANGE, AND CONCERNS IN THEIR IMMEDIATE COMMUNITY.  STUDENTS WILL TEACH FRIENDS AND NEIGHBORS ABOUT THE ENVIRONMENTAL INJUSTICE OF THE DISPROPORTIONATE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON THEIR NEIGHBORHOODS. THE TEACHERS AT THESE SCHOOLS WILL TAKE ADVANTAGE OF THE EDUCATIONAL VALUE PROVIDED BY A GREEN SCHOOLYARD AND BRING LOCAL WATERSHED EDUCATION INTO THE CLASSROOM. ANOTHER DELIVERABLE FOR THIS PROJECT IS THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A DEDICATED STEWARDSHIP COORDINATOR FOR PHILADELPHIA OFFICE OF THE TRUST FOR PUBLIC LAND. DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO JASTECH DEVELOPMENT SERVICES, INC. TO IMPLEMENT ITS PROJECT, WHICH WILL DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND DISSEMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PRACTICES, METHODS, AND TECHNIQUES THAT WILL SERVE TO INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND ENCOURAGE BEHAVIOR BENEFITTING THE ENVIRONMENT IN THE OVERBROOK SECTION OF PHILADELPHIA, PA. THE GRANTEE WILL DO THIS BY INCREASING PUBLIC AWARENESS AND KNOWLEDGE ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES BY PROVIDING PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS WITH THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS AND TO TAKE RESPONSIBLE ACTIONS IN THEIR COMMUNITY.

THE OVERBROOK COMMUNITY SCIENCE (OCS) PROJECT WILL SUPPORT EPA'S PRIORITIES FOR COMMUNITY PROJECTS THAT INCREASE PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING OF THE BENEFITS OF ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP THROUGH COMMUNITY COLLABORATION ON ISSUES OF CLIMATE AND ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY. THE OCS WILL PROVIDE RESOURCES FROM THE CITY AND STATE TO EDUCATE STAKEHOLDERS IN NON-FORMAL SETTINGS ON CAREER DEVELOPMENT, ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES AND SOLUTIONS, AND TEACH ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE AND LOCAL ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES.
	ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND KNOWLEDGE ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES IN WEST AND NORTH PHILADELPHIA AND PROVIDE THESE COMMUNITIES WITH THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS AND TAKE RESPONSIBLE ACTIONS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED DURING THIS PROJECT PERIOD INCLUDES FORMING A COMMUNITY ADVISORY BOARD (CAB) TO IMPLEMENT A REPLICABLE PILOT PROGRAM THAT FULFILS COMMUNITY-IDENTIFIED NEEDS FOR ADAPTING TO BURDENSOME CLIMATE AND ENVIRONMENTAL EXPOSURES. ALL PARTNERS AND SUB-AWARDEES WILL ASSIST IN THE OUTREACH AND IDENTIFICATION OF CITY-OWNED, VACANT LOTS IN THE OVERBROOK AND NORTH PHILADELPHIA SECTIONS OF PHILADELPHIA. 

THE OCS PLANS TO WORK WITH COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO IDENTIFY THEIR DESIRED USE AND WILL PROVIDE WORK TO REMOVE DEBRIS FROM UNDERSERVICED VACANT LOTS. FURTHERMORE, SUB-AWARDEES, ESPERANZA, IMPACT SERVICES, WYNNEFIELD OVERBROOK REVITALIZATION CORPORATION, AND PENNSYLVANIA HORTICULTURAL SOCIETY, WILL PROVIDE COMMUNITY OUTREACH WITH THE PHILADELPHIA COMMERCE DEPARTMENT. THE OCS WILL IDENTIFY NEEDS FOR ADAPTING TO CLIMATE CHANGE AND MOTIVATING NEIGHBORHOOD-LEVEL ACTIONS TO OVERCOME BURDENSOME ENVIRONMENTAL AND HEALTH EXPOSURES; SUPPORT THE INVENTORY OF VACANT LOTS; AND HELP CONVENE MEMBERS FOR THE CAB AND PARTICIPANTS FOR FOCUS GROUPS. THE OCS PLANS TO WORK WITH THESE COMMUNITIES FROM WEST AND NORTH PHILADELPHIA TO INSTALL AIR MONITORS IN APPROXIMATELY 42 HOMES.SUBRECIPIENT:THE OCS SUBAWARDEES, ESPERANZA, IMPACT SERVICES, WYNNEFIELD OVERBROOK REVITALIZATION CORPORATION AND PENNSYLVANIA HORTICULTURAL SOCIETY WILL PROVIDE COMMUNITY OUTREACH WITH THE PHILADELPHIA COMMERCE DEPARTMENT'S - PHILADELPHIA TAKING CARE OF BUSINESS CORRIDOR (PHL TBC) STAFF MEMBERS. THEY WILL INFORM COMMUNITY MEMBERS ON OUTCOMES OF THE PILOT TO FULFIL COMMUNITY-IDENTIFIED NEEDS FOR ADAPTING TO CLIMATE CHANGE AND MOTIVATING NEIGHBORHOOD-LEVEL ACTIONS TO OVERCOME BURDENSOME ENVIRONMENTAL AND HEALTH EXPOSURES, SUPPORT THE INVENTORY OF VACANT LOTS, HELP CONVENE MEMBERS FOR THE COMMUNITY ADVISORY BOARD AND PARTICIPANTS FOR FOCUS GROUPS.OUTCOMES:IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE FOLLOWING DELIVERABLES: FORMING A COMMUNITY ADVISORY BOARD TO PARTICIPATE IN THE CAMPAIGN PROCESS; CONDUCTING FOCUS GROUPS TO IDENTIFY KEY BEHAVIORAL TARGETS AND BETTER UNDERSTAND TARGET AUDIENCE PERCEPTIONS OF BARRIERS AND BENEFITS OF KEY BEHAVIORAL TARGETS; PERFORMING SAMPLING AND LEAD EXPOSURE RISK ANALYSIS; ASSESSING VACANT PROPERTIES IN THE SPECIFIED DISTRICTS; DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING THE COMMUNITY-BASED CAMPAIGN IN A PARTICIPATORY MANNER, UTILIZING EXISTING ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH RESOURCES (E.G., EPA NONPOINT SOURCE OUTREACH TOOLBOX, OEEC EDUCATION PROGRAM, EPA, CDC, AND AD COUNCIL LEAD POISONING PREVENTION OUTREACH MATERIALS); AND, IMPLEMENTING A FOLLOW-UP COMMUNITY TRAINING AND ASSESS THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE CAMPAIGN

THE EARTH CONSERVATION CORPS (ECC) TEAM, UNDER THE GUIDANCE OF THE NATIONAL WILDLIFE FEDERATION, WILL PROVIDE A SERIES OF TRAINING WORKSHOPS IN WHICH THEY WILL PRESENT AN INTRODUCTION OF THE PHILOSOPHY AND CURRICULUM OF THE ECO-SCHOOLS USA PROGRAM.  UPON COMPLETION OF THE INITIAL TRAINING, THE TEACHERS WILL IMPLEMENT THE ECO-SCHOOLS PROGRAM WITH THEIR STUDENTS.  STUDENTS WILL BE CHALLENGED TO WORK IN COOPERATIVE ECO-ACTION TEAMS TO EVALUATE THE SUSTAINABILITY OF THEIR SCHOOL AND USE THEIR CRITICAL THINKING SKILLS TO DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT A SUSTAINABILITY CAMPAIGN AROUND A CONSERVATION TOPIC IN THEIR SCHOOL. TEACHERS WILL THEN PARTICIPATE IN ADDITIONAL TRAINING, REFLECTION AND PLANNING, SUPPORTED BY THE ECC, TO PLAN AND IMPLEMENT ANOTHER ECO-SCHOOLS MODULE FOCUSED ON A DIFFERENT CONSERVATION TOPIC. THIS WILL ALLOW TEACHERS TO GAIN A HIGH LEVEL OF FAMILIARITY WITH THE CURRICULUM, EMBEDDING THIS ACTION-ORIENTED SUSTAINABILITY MODEL IN THEIR PRACTICE AT THEIR SCHOOLS.

THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT WILL HELP ACHIEVE THE OVERALL GOAL OF CONNECTING HIGH SCHOOL ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE STUDENTS TO THE JAMES RIVER AND PROVIDE BOTH IN-CLASS AND OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES. THIS PROJECT WILL ENGAGE RICHMOND PUBLIC HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS THROUGHOUT THE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION CONTINUUM RELATED TO RICHMOND'S LARGEST CONTRIBUTOR TO DEGRADED LOCAL WATER QUALITY: STORMWATER RUNOFF AND THE COMBINED SEWER SYSTEM (CSS).

HERITAGE CONSERVANCY AND ITS PARTNERS WILL EDUCATE AND EMPOWER STUDENTS TO ENVIRONMENTAL ACTION THROUGH IN CLASSROOM PROGRAMS AND CROSS-WATERSHED COLLABORATION PAIRED WITH OUTDOOR FIELD TRIPS THAT INTEGRATE LESSONS RELATED TO SINGLE-USE PLASTICS, RECYCLING, AND OVERALL WATERSHED PROTECTION THROUGH DECREASED TRASH POLLUTION. WITH PARTNER HELP, COMMUNITY OUTREACH WILL INVOLVE OPTIONS FOR INDIVIDUALS TO SIGN PLEDGES, VOLUNTEER ON ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP PROJECTS (TRASH CLEANUPS, WATER RESOURCES PROTECTION), AND DIRECTLY CHANGE THEIR DAILY BEHAVIORS RELATED TO THE IMPACTS OF SINGLE-USE PLASTICS.

THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT PROVIDES THE LIVING LOCAL PROJECT AGRICULTURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF AN INTERDISCIPLINARY LEARNING MODULE, STUDENT EXPERIENCES, AND COMMUNITY WORKSHOPS THAT ADDRESS ENVIRONMENTAL AND HUMAN IMPACTS AFFECTING AGRICULTURE AND THE BENEFITS BEST FARM PRACTICES HAVE ON MARYLAND'S WATER RESOURCES COASTAL BAYS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL PROMOTE A CULTURE OF ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP AND LITERACY THROUGH HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES ON LOCAL FARMS AND SCHOOLS IN WORCESTER COUNTY, MARYLAND.

THIS ORGANIZATION WILL PROVIDE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR TEACHERS ON THE ISSUES AND IMPORTANCE OF THEIR LOCAL WATERSHEDS, HOW TO TEACH THEIR STUDENTS ABOUT THE ISSUES, AND HOW TO ENGAGE THEIR STUDENTS IN PROBLEM-SOLVING AND STEWARDSHIP ACTIVITIES.  THE PROJECT WILL PROMOTE A PERSONAL RIVER AND BAY PROTECTION ETHIC (ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY) IN PARTICIPANTS THROUGH ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS AND ACTIVITIES.  IT WILL ALSO PROVIDE A TANGIBLE RESTORATION BENEFIT TO THE RAPPAHANNOCK RIVER AND CHESAPEAKE BAY THROUGH RIVER STEWARDSHIP PROGRAMS AND ACTIVITIES.

THE BOTANICAL GARDEN WILL PROVIDE EDUCATION AND OPPORTUNITIES FOR VOLUNTEERS IN THE COMMUNITY REGARDING THE ORGANIZATION'S WORK ON PREVENTING STORM WATER RUN-OFF INTO A LOCAL LAKE BY PLANTING NATIVE SPECIES OF PLANTS ALONG THE SHORELINE, REMOVING INVASIVE PLANTS, CORRECTING THE GRADING, AND INSTALLING A RAIN GARDEN.  THIS PROJECT ALSO PROPOSES TO PROTECT AND IMPROVE WATER QUALITY IN THE CHESAPEAKE BAY WATERSHED BY MANAGING STORMWATER RUN-OFF ALONG ITS SYDNOR KAKE SHORELINE.  THE PROJECT WILL PRESENT EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES ABOUT WATER QUALITY BMP'S, RESTORATION METHODOLOGY, RAINGARDEN FUNCTION AND THE DIVERSE PALETTE OF NATIVE PLANTS THAT THRIVE IN CHALLENGING CONDITIONS.

THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE IMPLEMENTATION/EXTENSION OF TWO KEY ELEMENTS IN MASONVILLE COVE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION CAMPUS (MCEEC) EXISTING ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PLAN.  1. AN ADVANCED EXPANSION OF THE WELL ESTABLISHED SCHOOL LEADERSHIP IN URBAN RUNOFF REDUCTION PROJECT (SLURRP) AND 2. COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT EVENTS AND PROGRAMS THAT ENGAGE RESIDENTS OF ALL AGES IN ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY ACTIVITIES AND HANDS-ON-STEWARDSHIP.  SLURRP IS A RICHLY STRUCTURED, PROJECT BASED LEARNING EXPERIENCE THAT SUPPORTS ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND INCREASES AWARENESS OF STORM WATER RUNOFF POLLUTION AND HOW TO PREVENT IT.

THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE BALTIMORE CITY PUBLIC HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS THE OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN ABOUT LIVING-WAGE, GREEN CAREERS AND PROVIDE THE PATHWAYS TO ACHIEVE THEM. THIS PROJECT IS DESIGNED TO PROVIDE LEARNING THAT MOVES YOUTH ALONG THE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION CONTINUUM, FROM ACQUIRING AWARENESS AND KNOWLEDGE TO PROBLEM SOLVING, DECISION-MAKING AND ACTIVE STEWARDSHIP. THIS PROJECT WILL EDUCATE YOUTH ABOUT ECO'S SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION PRACTICES AND THEN PROMPT THEM TO THINK ABOUT WAYS THEY CAN IMPLEMENT THESE PRACTICES IN A HOME OR SCHOOL SETTING. THE PROJECT CHALLENGES THEM TO QUESTION THEIR ROLE IN THE LOCAL FOOD SYSTEM AND SOIL REGENERATION, AND TAKE ADDITIONAL STEPS BEYOND THE CLASSROOM AND FIELD TRIP EXPERIENCES, TO BECOME INVOLVED IN LOCAL ACTION AND ENVIRONMENTAL DECISION-MAKING.

THIS PROJECT'S GOALS ARE: 1) ENGAGE STUDENTS AND THE PUBLIC IN CITIZEN SCIENCE (CS) EFFORTS, TO 2) PROVIDE MEANINGFUL ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION AND STEWARDSHIP RESTORATION OPPORTUNITIES LINKED TO THIS CS EFFORT, THAT WILL 3) IMPROVE WATER QUALITY OF LOCAL STREAM(S) WHILE INCREASING PARTICIPANTS' ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY. THIS INNOVATIVE PROJECT WILL USE CS AS THE BROAD 'PORTAL' INTO ENVIRONMENTAL ENGAGEMENT, EDUCATION, AND SCIENCE. THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP AND INTEGRATE A LOCALLY FOCUSED WATER QUALITY MONITORING CS PROJECT WITH AN ENVIRONMENTAL RESTORATION PROJECT TO ADDRESS ECOLOGICAL AND EDUCATION OUTCOMES FOR A VARIETY OF PARTICIPANTS.

THROUGH A COMBINATION OF PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT, THE PROJECT WILL REACH EDUCATORS, WITH CO-PLANNED LESSONS REACH STUDENTS AND ADULTS, WITH WORKSHOPS REACH PARENTS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS.  THIS APPROACH ALLOWS THE ALLIANCE TO CONNECT PEOPLE TO LOCAL WATERSHED ISSUES, GUIDE PEOPLE BEYOND AWARENESS TO BEING ABLE TO CRITICALLY THINK ABOUT CONSERVATION EFFORTS AND MAKE DECISIONS ABOUT THEIR WATERSHED FOOTPRINT AND ULTIMATELY CHANGE THEIR BEHAVIORS AND ACTIONS TO BETTER PROTECT AND HELP RESTORE LOCAL STREAMS AND RIVERS.

JOHN AND PROVIDE COLLEGE STUDENTS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS AS WELL AS TAKE RESPONSIBLE ACTIONS. DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO THE UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO AT AGUADILLA TO IMPLEMENT ITS PROJECT, WHICH WILL DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND DISSEMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PRACTICES, METHODS, AND TECHNIQUES, THAT WILL SERVE TO INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND ENCOURAGE BEHAVIOR THAT WILL BENEFIT THE ENVIRONMENT IN THE RURAL AREAS OF AGUADA, AGUADILLA AND MOCO, PUERTO RICO. THE RECIPIENT WILL DO THIS BY INCREASING UNDERGRADUATE AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS' KNOWLEDGE OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND AIR QUALITY ISSUES AFFECTING THEIR COMMUNITIES THROUGH ITS SEARCHING OUR ENVIRONMENT (BETA) PROJECT USING PROBLEM-BASED LEARNING AND HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES. ALSO, THE UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO WILL GIVE STUDENTS A HEIGHTENED KNOWLEDGE OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND THE RISKS IT POSES BY LOOKING AT IMPACTS IN THEIR COMMUNITIES. THIS PROJECT WILL INCLUDE ASSESSING WEATHER PATTERNS, CHANGES IN AIR QUALITY, COASTAL EROSION AND SEA LEVEL RISING. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, THE RECIPIENT INTENDS TO EMPOWER UNDERGRADUATES AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS AND TAKE ACTION TO REDUCE THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE AFFECTING THEIR COMMUNITIES.   	ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND KNOWLEDGE ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES IN AGUADA, AGUADILLA AND MOCO, PUERTO RICO AND PROVIDE UNDERGRADUATES AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS AND TO TAKE RESPONSIBLE ACTIONS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED DURING THIS PROJECT PERIOD INCLUDE: INSTRUCTIONAL WORKSHOP MATERIAL, PROVIDE TRAINING TO UNDERGRADUATE AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, LEADING FIELD TRIPS AND TESTING AIR AND WATER QUALITY.  SUBRECIPIENT:THE RECIPIENT INTENDS TO ISSUE SUBAWARDS AS REQUIRED UNDER THE NATIONAL ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION ACT.  THE SUBAWARDEES WILL COORDINATE PROJECT ACTIVITIES, DEVELOP TRAINING MATERIALS AND PRESENT TRAINING TO THE PROJECT PARTICIPANTS. OUTCOMES:IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE FOLLOWING DELIVERABLES AND OUTCOMES: DEVELOP INSTRUCTIONAL WORKSHOP MATERIALS AND CONDUCT 18 WORKSHOPS FOR APPROXIMATELY 200 UNDERGRADUATE AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, AND EMPOWER THE PROJECT PARTICIPANTS TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS AS WELL AS TAKING ACTION TO REDUCE THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE AFFECTING THEIR LOCAL COMMUNITIES. THE DIRECT BENEFICIARIES ARE UNDERGRADUATE AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS LOCATED IN AGUADA, AGUADILLA AND MOCO, PUERTO, RICO.

DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO GROUNDWORKS HUDSON VALLEY TO IMPLEMENT ITS PROJECT, WHICH WILL DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND DISSEMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PRACTICES, METHODS, AND TECHNIQUES, THAT WILL SERVE TO INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND ENCOURAGE BEHAVIOR THAT WILL BENEFIT THE ENVIRONMENT IN YONKERS, NEW YORK. GROUNDWORKS HUDSON VALLEY WILL USE CLASSROOM AND HANDS-ON FIELD EXPERIENCE TO TEACH STUDENTS ABOUT WATER QUALITY, STORMWATER MANAGEMENT, CLIMATE CHANGE RESILIENCY, AND HOW TO PREPARE FOR DISASTERS SUCH AS FLOODS AND HURRICANES. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED DURING THIS PROJECT PERIOD INCLUDE: RECRUITMENT OF TEACHERS AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS, DEVELOP AND DELIVER THE CLASSROOM LESSONS ON WATER QUALITY, STORMWATER MANAGEMENT, CLIMATE RESILIENCY TO PROJECT PARTICIPANTS; AND INSTALL FIVE GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS SUCH AS RAIN GARDENS, NATIVE SPECIES PLANTING, RIPARIAN BUFFERS AND HILLSIDE STABILIZATION TO MITIGATE THE IMPACT OF STORMWATER AND FLOODING IN THE LOCAL AFFECTED COMMUNITY. THE SUBAWARDEES WILL PROVIDE COORDINATION OF PROJECT ACTIVITIES AND ASSISTING STUDENTS IN THE DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS IN PRIORITY LOCATIONS TO ASSIST IN THE MITIGATION RELATED TO THE IMPACT OF FLOODING IN THE LOCAL AFFECTED COMMUNITY. OUTCOMES:IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE FOLLOWING DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: INCREASING THE KNOWLEDGE OF MORE THAN 300 STUDENTS OF PROBLEM AWARENESS, STEM KNOWLEDGE, CRITICAL THINKING AND DECISION-MAKING SKILLS ON LOCAL  WATER QUALITY, STORMWATER MANAGEMENT, CLIMATE RESILIENCY AND EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS RELATED TO FLOODING IN THE AFFECTED AREA; DELIVERY OF THREE LESSON MODULES FOR PROJECT PARTICIPANTS; AND IMPLEMENT FIVE GREEN INFRASTRUCTURE PROJECTS IN THE LOCAL COMMUNITY TO MITIGATE FLOODING . DIRECT BENEFICIARIES ARE STUDENTS LOCATED IN YONKERS, NEW YORK.

DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO BERGEN COMMUNITY COLLEGE TO IMPLEMENT ITS PROJECT, WHICH WILL DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND DISSEMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PRACTICES, METHODS, AND TECHNIQUES, THAT WILL SERVE TO INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND ENCOURAGE BEHAVIOR THAT WILL BENEFIT THE ENVIRONMENT IN BERGEN, ESSEX, AND PASSAIC COUNTIES IN NEW JERSEY. THE GRANTEE WILL DO THIS BY EDUCATING UNDERSERVED HIGH SCHOOL AND COLLEGE STUDENTS ON SOLID WASTE ISSUES AFFECTING THEIR COMMUNITIES. BERGEN COMMUNITY COLLEGE WILL USE A COMBINATION OF CLASSROOM COURSE, HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES, TO TEACH STUDENTS HOW SOLID WASTE CAN IMPACT THEIR LOCAL COMMUNITY, HOW TO MITIGATE METHANE FROM LANDFILLS, INCREASE COMPOSTING, AND REDUCE STORMWATER EROSION AND REHABILITATE SOIL.  ALSO, THE RECIPIENT, WILL TEACH THE STUDENTS HOW TO DO ORGANIC RECYCLING AND COMPOSTING TO REDUCE FOOD WASTE. THIS PROJECT WILL RAISE THE ENVIRONMENTAL KNOWLEDGE OF PROJECT PARTICIPANTS AND INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP RELATED TO SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT WITHIN THE AFFECTED UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES.  ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND KNOWLEDGE ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES IN BERGEN, ESSEX, AND PASSAIC COUNTIES, NEW JERSEY AND PROVIDE HIGH SCHOOL AND COLLEGE STUDENTS THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS AS WELL AS TAKE RESPONSIBLE ACTIONS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED DURING THIS PROJECT PERIOD INCLUDE DEVELOPING LESSON PLANS AND TRAINING MATERIALS FOR THE STUDENTS, TRAINING AND TEACHING, RECRUITING PROJECT PARTICIPANTS, COMPOSTING, AND STUDENT LED DESIGNED PROJECTS TO REDUCE SOLID WASTE USING BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. THE SUB AWARDEES WILL PROVIDE COORDINATION OF THE PROJECT, PREPARING EDUCATION MATERIALS FIELD TRIPS AND HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES.  SUBAWARDS ARE INCLUDED IN THIS ASSISTANCE AGREEMENT. OUTCOMES:IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE FOLLOWING DELIVERABLES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: 100 COLLEGE STUDENTS AND 500 HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS WILL INCREASE THEIR KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING OF SOLID WASTE MANAGEMENT, ORGANIC RECYCLING AND COMPOSTING TO REDUCE FOOD WASTE. ALSO, THROUGH THIS PROJECT, IT IS EXPECTED TO REDUCE AND DIVERT 25% OF SCHOOL AND COMMUNITIES FOOD WASTE FROM LANDFILL. DIRECT BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE STUDENTS AND RESIDENTS LOCATED IN BERGEN, ESSEX AND PASSAIC COUNTIES, NEW JERSEY.

DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO PROJECT WET TO IMPLEMENT ITS PROJECT, WHICH WILL DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND DISSEMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PRACTICES, METHODS, AND TECHNIQUES, THAT WILL SERVE TO INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND ENCOURAGE BEHAVIOR THAT WILL BENEFIT THE ENVIRONMENT IN MONTANA. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED DURING THIS PROJECT PERIOD INCLUDE: EXPERIENCED TRAINERS FROM PROJECT WET WILL CONDUCT 10 PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRAINING WORKSHOPS FOR EDUCATORS IN UNDERSERVED RURAL AND URBAN COMMUNITIES IN MONTANA, BUILDING CAPACITY FOR THEM TO TEACH ABOUT CLIMATE CHANGE IN MONTANA AND IN THEIR COMMUNITIES.  PROJECT WET WILL RECRUIT EDUCATORS FROM FOUR TRIBAL NATIONS, 10 TITLE I OR TARGETED ASSISTANCE SCHOOLS, AND 10 DIFFERENT COMMUNITIES AROUND MONTANA TO ATTEND EDUCATOR TRAININGS, RECEIVE STIPENDS, CONTINUING EDUCATION UNITS (CEUS) AND BECOME ECO-SCHOOL AND WATERSTAR CERTIFIED. SUBRECIPIENT:SUB-AWARDS WILL BE GIVEN TO FIVE EDUCATIONAL AND/OR ENVIRONMENTAL ORGANIZATIONS TO ORGANIZE A CLIMATE, WATER AND RESILIENCE TRAINING AND TO AWARD FUNDS TO SCHOOLS THAT PARTICIPATE IN WATERSTAR CERTIFICATION. RECIPIENTS WILL INCLUDE SCHOOL SERVICES OF MONTANA (SSOM), MONTANA ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION ASSOCIATION (MEEA), MONTANA OUTDOOR SCIENCE SCHOOL (MOSS), AND TWO OTHER NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATIONS WORKING WITH EDUCATION IN MONTANA.  SUBAWARDS WILL BE IN THE AMOUNT OF $5,000 EACH WITH FUNDING FOR SUBAWARDS FROM EPA TOTALING EXACTLY $25,000.  OUTCOMES:IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN THE FOLLOWING DELIVERABLES:

-EDUCATE 2,500 MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS ABOUT CLIMATE CHANGE GLOBALLY AND CLIMATE TRENDS IN MONTANA.
-COMPLETE CLIMATE RESILIENCE PROJECTS IN 25 SCHOOLS OR ORGANIZATIONS AS PART OF THE WATERSTAR PROGRAM.

EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THE PROJECT INCLUDE: 
-INTEGRATE CLIMATE AND WATER TOPICS INTO SCHOOLS' CURRICULUM ACROSS MONTANA.
-INCREASE KNOWLEDGE ABOUT CLIMATE DATA AND CLIMATE CHANGE IN 2,500 MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL MONTANA YOUTH.
-DEVELOP AN ETHIC OF WATER AND ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP IN 2,500 MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOL MONTANA YOUTH.

DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO LEFT HAND WATERSHED OVERSIGHT GROUP TO IMPLEMENT ITS PROJECT, WHICH WILL DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND DISSEMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PRACTICES, METHODS, AND TECHNIQUES, THAT WILL SERVE TO INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND ENCOURAGE BEHAVIOR THAT WILL BENEFIT STUDENTS AND TEACHERS IN THE ENVIRONMENT IN THE ST. VRAIN WATERSHED IN COLORADO. THE ST. VRAIN WATERSHED IN COLORADO IS AT HIGH RISK OF CATASTROPHIC WILDFIRE, WHICH WOULD RESULT IN POOR WATER QUALITY, RISK TO COMMUNITY SAFETY, AND DECLINE OF FORESTED ECOSYSTEMS. IN RESPONSE, EDUCATION EFFORTS THAT INCREASE THE ABILITY OF COMMUNITIES TO BUILD RESILIENCE TO FLOOD AND FIRE ARE URGENTLY NEEDED. THE GRANTEE WILL DO THIS THROUGH THREE MAIN PROGRAMS: P1) INQUIRY-BASED 5TH GRADE CURRICULUM DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION WHICH WILL BE PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE AND BUILT ON ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT PROCESSES AND PROTOCOLS USED BY SCIENTISTS AND LAND MANAGERS, P2) WORKSHOPS FOR TEACHERS THAT PROVIDE THEM WITH EXPERIENCE AND TOOLS TO IMPLEMENT THIS CURRICULUM IN THEIR CLASSROOMS, AND P3) HIGHER EDUCATION AND LEADERSHIP OPPORTUNITIES FOR HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS THAT PREPARE THEM TO BE ENVIRONMENTAL SCHOLARS AND LEADERS IN THEIR COMMUNITIES. 


ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND KNOWLEDGE ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES IN THE ST. VRAIN WATERSHED IN COLORADO AND PROVIDE STUDENTS AND TEACHERS THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS AND TO TAKE RESPONSIBLE ACTIONS.  ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED DURING THIS PROJECT PERIOD INCLUDE: THE PROJECT WILL TEACH THE CURRICULUM IN AN ELEMENTARY SCHOOL THAT LIES AT THE WILDLAND URBAN INTERFACE, WHOSE STUDENTS ARE AT RISK OF BEING DIRECTLY IMPACTED BY FIRE AND FLOOD, AS WELL AS AT AN ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION CENTER WHICH SERVES 4,500 5TH GRADERS ACROSS TWO SCHOOL DISTRICTS AND 350 LATINO FAMILIES PER YEAR (45% OF THEIR PARTICIPANTS ARE PEOPLE OF COLOR AND LINGUISTICALLY DIVERSE). DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO COLORADO ALLIANCE FOR ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION (CAEE) TO IMPLEMENT ITS PROJECT, WHICH WILL DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND DISSEMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PRACTICES, METHODS, AND TECHNIQUES, THAT WILL SERVE TO INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND ENCOURAGE BEHAVIOR THAT WILL BENEFIT THE ENVIRONMENT IN REGION 8. THE GRANTEE WILL DO THIS BY  CREATING A FRAMEWORK TO DEVELOP, DELIVER, AND SUSTAIN COMPREHENSIVE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR EDUCATORS ACROSS REGION 8 STATES (CO, WY, MT AND UT). BY DEVELOPING AND DELIVERING AN EECREDENTIAL PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM TO ENSURE RIGOROUS, EFFECTIVE, AND ACCESSIBLE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT GROUNDED IN THE NAAEE GUIDELINES FOR EXCELLENCE, THE GRANTEE WILL PREPARE FORMAL AND NON-FORMAL EDUCATORS IN REGION 8 TO ADDRESS CLIMATE CHANGE WITH THEIR LEARNERS. THE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES DEVELOPED AS A RESULT OF THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE EDUCATORS WITH THE SKILLS AND KNOWLEDGE THEY NEED TO DELIVER EFFECTIVE, HIGH-QUALITY ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION THAT HELPS LEARNERS WEIGH VARIOUS SIDES OF ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES AND DEVELOP CRITICAL THINKING, PROBLEM SOLVING AND DECISION-MAKING SKILLS. DESCRIPTION:THIS PROJECT PROVIDES FUNDING TO WILDLAND RESTORATION VOLUNTEERS (WRV) TO IMPLEMENT ITS PROJECT, WHICH WILL DESIGN, DEMONSTRATE, AND DISSEMINATE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PRACTICES, METHODS, AND TECHNIQUES, THAT WILL SERVE TO INCREASE ENVIRONMENTAL LITERACY AND ENCOURAGE BEHAVIOR THAT WILL BENEFIT THE ENVIRONMENT IN COMMUNITIES IN COLORADO. THE GRANTEE WILL DO THIS BY WORKING WITH COMMUNITIES TO ADDRESS LOCAL CLIMATE CHANGE EFFECTS AND RESTORATION PROJECTS.  COMBINED EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND POPULATION GROWTH HAVE HAD SIGNIFICANT IMPACTS ON COLORADO'S AIR AND WATER QUALITY. 2020 WAS THE STATE'S MOST ACTIVE FIRE SEASON, AND RESIDENTS ALONG THE FRONT RANGE EXPERIENCED POOR AIR QUALITY THROUGHOUT THE SUMMER MONTHS, PARTICULARLY IN LOW-INCOME AREAS THAT ALREADY EXPERIENCED HIGH LEVELS OF OZONE POLLUTION FROM INDUSTRY AND TRANSPORTATION. RUNOFF CAUSED BY WILDFIRE AND OTHER FORMS OF ENVIRONMENTAL DEGRADATION HAVE ALSO CONTAMINATED WATER QUALITY, WHILE GROWING POPULATIONS HAVE EXACERBATED THE EFFECTS. THESE IMPACTS TRANSCEND LOCAL BOUNDARIES AND HAVE NEGATIVE IMPACTS ON THE HEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF RESIDENTS IN BOTH RURAL AND URBAN AREAS ACROSS THE STATE.

TO ENSURE THAT PROJECTS ADDRESS LOCAL IMPACTS THAT ARE MOST RELEVANT TO TARGET COMMUNITIES, WRV IS TAKING A COMMUNITY-BASED APPROACH, PARTNERING WITH ORGANIZATIONS ROOTED IN THESE COMMUNITIES IN ORDER TO MEET THE NEEDS OF COMMUNITY MEMBERS. FOR EXAMPLE, IN NORTHEAST DENVER, AMONG THE MOST POLLUTED AREAS IN THE COUNTRY, THEY WILL WORK WITH LOCAL PARTNERS SUCH AS HIGH LINE CANAL CONSERVANCY AND ENVIRONMENTAL LEARNING FOR KIDS TO PLANT TREES IN NEIGHBORHOODS HEAVILY IMPACTED BY POOR AIR QUALITY. IN LAFAYETTE AND LONGMONT, PROJECTS WILL FOCUS ON RIPARIAN CORRIDORS SUCH AS COAL CREEK AND ST. VRAIN, PARTICULARLY WHERE THESE WATERWAYS RUN THROUGH LOW-INCOME NEIGHBORHOODS.
ACTIVITIES:THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND KNOWLEDGE ABOUT ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES IN COLORADO AND PROVIDE YOUTH, FAMILIES, AND YOUNG ADULTS FROM LOW-INCOME,
PRIMARILY LATINX COMMUNITIES THE SKILLS NECESSARY TO MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS AND TO TAKE RESPONSIBLE ACTIONS. ACTIVITIES TO BE PERFORMED DURING THIS PROJECT PERIOD INCLUDE: ACTIVITIES OVER TWO YEARS WILL INCLUDE A RESTORATION YOUTH CORPS FOR 20 LOW-INCOME TEENS; TRAINING 40 PARTICIPANTS AS COMMUNITY LEADERS THROUGH FOUR BILINGUAL RESTORATION LEADERSHIP TRAININGS; AND ENGAGING 400 VOLUNTEERS ON AT LEAST 16 HIGH-IMPACT STEWARDSHIP PROJECTS. PARTICIPANTS WILL GAIN INCREASED ACCESS AND CONNECTIONS TO NATURE; BUILD SKILLS AND CAPACITY TO IDENTIFY AND ADDRESS LOCAL ENVIRONMENTAL CHALLENGES; AND GAIN ACCESS TO CAREER PATHWAYS IN ENVIRONMENTAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES.SUBRECIPIENT:TRAINING ON DIVERSITY, EQUITY, INCLUSION AND ACCESSIBILITY - WRV WILL ALLOCATE $5,000 IN SUBAWARD FUNDS TO PROVIDE TRAINING ON ENGAGING DIVERSE COMMUNITIES FOR 200 VOLUNTEERS OR PARTNERS. THIS PROJECT WILL WORK ENTIRELY WITH UNDERSERVED (LOW-INCOME COMMUNITIES AND COMMUNITIES OF COLOR), SO IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT WE PRIORITIZE CREATING AN INCLUSIVE AND EQUITABLE ENVIRONMENT. WRV WILL ALLOCATE $4,000 IN SUBAWARD FUNDING TO THE OUTDOOR STEWARDSHIP INSTITUTE (OSI), A STATE LEADER IN PROVIDING TRAININGS ON ECOLOGICAL STEWARDSHIP AND OUTDOOR LEADERSHIP; TRAININGS ARE CREATED IN COLLABORATION BETWEEN WRV, VOLUNTEERS FOR OUTDOOR COLORADO, AND OTHER ORGANIZATIONS. SUBAWARD FUNDING WILL SUPPORT THE TRANSLATION OF OSI WRITTEN MATERIALS AND ONLINE TRAININGS INTO SPANISH AND ENSURE THAT TRAININGS ARE CULTURALLY RELEVANT AND INCLUSIVE. IN DOING SO, WRV WILL ENSURE THAT VOLUNTEERS AND STEWARDSHIP PROFESSIONALS STATEWIDE, RATHER THAN JUST OUR OWN COMMUNITY, HAVE ACCESS TO SPANISH-LANGUAGE MATERIALS.
